title: User & Client Interviews
overview: Interview clients and users to uncover real needs and impacts beyond functional requirements.
purpose: Collect insights from both clients (strategic goals, risks) and users (daily tasks, accessibility). Surface functional needs as well as social and ecological impacts to guide responsible design.

steps.title: Prepare Questions
steps.description: Write 3–5 open-ended questions covering functional, social, and ecological aspects.

steps.title: Identify Interviewee Type
steps.description: Adapt questions for clients (goals, risks) or users (tasks, pains, accessibility).

steps.title: Run the Interview
steps.description: Interview one person at a time. Let them speak freely and avoid yes/no questions.

steps.title: Capture Responses
steps.description: Take notes on answers, examples, and non-verbal cues.

steps.title: Summarize Findings
steps.description: Review notes as a team and extract key insights and sustainability considerations.

input: Notebook or template for capturing responses
prompts: I am preparing an interview about [project]. Suggest 5–7 open-ended questions covering functional, social, and ecological aspects.
I am interviewing a [client/user] about [project]. Suggest polite follow-up questions to get richer insights when answers are vague.
Here are my raw interview notes: [paste notes]. Summarize insights into three categories: functional needs, social impacts, ecological impacts.
Based on these findings: [paste summary], suggest areas to explore further to address sustainability in the design.
tips: Start with 'Tell me about…' instead of yes/no questions.
Let interviewees talk 80% of the time.
Ask follow-ups like 'Can you give an example?'
Check if notes capture both people and planet impacts.
For clients: focus on long-term goals and risks.
For users: focus on routines, frustrations, accessibility.

title: Stakeholder Impact Map
overview: Map human, non-human, and systemic stakeholders to understand impacts across levels.
purpose: Identify all actors affected by your product, including ecosystems. Reveal who might be excluded or vulnerable and design with broader ethical awareness.

steps.title: Place Your System
steps.description: Write your product, service, or concept in the center of the map.

steps.title: Add Human Actors
steps.description: Include users, clients, workers, and communities.

steps.title: Add Non-human Actors
steps.description: List technologies, infrastructures, ecosystems, rules, or species involved or impacted.

steps.title: Map Impacts
steps.description: Capture effects at three levels: Individual (micro), Social (meso), Environmental/Systemic (macro).

steps.title: Review & Reflect
steps.description: Check who is missing (marginalized groups, invisible workers, future generations).

input: Basic knowledge of your product or problem space
Template or whiteboard for mapping impacts
prompts: I am mapping stakeholders for [project]. Suggest relevant human and non-human actors.
Here is my stakeholder list: [paste list]. Identify excluded or vulnerable groups, including ecosystems or future generations.
For my system [name], summarize impacts at three levels: Individual, Social, Environmental/Systemic.
Based on these impacts [paste notes], suggest questions to ensure no groups or risks are overlooked.
tips: Be specific — name actual groups, not 'society'.
Push beyond obvious users to include invisible actors.
Always check impacts at all three levels.
Revisit and refine as your project evolves.
Use Conscious Digital Product Principles to reflect.

title: Inclusive User Groups
overview: Highlight diverse user groups to avoid stereotypes and include marginalized voices.
purpose: Make user groups visible without oversimplifying. Check privilege and exclusion risks while building balanced user stories.

steps.title: Fill in Group Data
steps.description: Use real data on demographics, abilities, or safety.

steps.title: Check Privilege
steps.description: Use the Wheel of Power to assess advantages and disadvantages.

steps.title: Define Group Role
steps.description: Describe their relation to your product (e.g., daily user, decision-maker).

steps.title: Capture Needs & Pains
steps.description: List access barriers, time constraints, or usability issues.

steps.title: List Gains
steps.description: Identify benefits this group gets from your product.

steps.title: Write User Story
steps.description: Summarize with 'As a [role], I want [needs/pains], so that [gains]'.

prompts: I am designing for a user group: [describe group]. Suggest data points to collect (age, abilities, safety, etc.).
For this group [describe], list potential struggles and barriers when using [product/service].
Based on this description [group], analyze privileges and disadvantages they may face.
Create a user story for this group: [paste group info].
tips: Be specific (e.g., 'international student on a budget').
Base details on data, not assumptions.
Ask: Who is missing? Include marginalized groups.
Combine with Systemic Journey Maps for context.

title: Systemic Journey Map
overview: Map user journeys step by step, including social and ecological impacts.
purpose: Break down experiences into clear phases. Link design choices to social and environmental effects, uncovering who is impacted and how.

steps.title: Define User Story
steps.description: Anchor the map with a user story or scenario.

steps.title: Set Journey Phases
steps.description: Break experiences into stages or steps.

steps.title: Capture Actions
steps.description: Write down what users do at each phase.

steps.title: Add Goals
steps.description: Describe what users want to achieve.

steps.title: Identify Pain Points
steps.description: List struggles or missing resources.

steps.title: List Gains
steps.description: Highlight benefits for users at each stage.

steps.title: Map Environmental Impacts
steps.description: Note effects on energy, waste, or resources.

steps.title: Map Social Impacts
steps.description: Record effects on inclusion, fairness, equity.

steps.title: Consider Orders of Impact
steps.description: Add first-, second-, and third-order effects.

steps.title: Add Data & Insights
steps.description: Include supporting data or findings.

input: Understanding of product or service flow
Awareness of social and ecological factors
prompts: I am mapping a journey for [project]. Suggest 5 phases and key actions for each.
For this journey [details], list goals, pains, and gains at each phase.
For this journey [details], identify possible social and environmental impacts.
Based on this journey map [details], describe first-, second-, and third-order impacts.
tips: Go beyond actions — ask why each step matters long term.
Start simple, then refine.
Consider impacts on community and environment.
Keep it visual and concise.
Check against Conscious Digital Product Principles.

title: Conscious Requirements
overview: Turn user stories into concrete scenarios, mapping actors and interactions.
purpose: Translate needs into use cases. Highlight dependencies, risks, and sustainability issues before implementation.

steps.title: Start with a User Story
steps.description: Write in the format: 'As a [role], I want [needs/pains], so that [gains]'.

steps.title: Add Actors
steps.description: Identify people, systems, or tools involved.

steps.title: Create Use Cases
steps.description: Define what each actor does to achieve the goal.

steps.title: Show Flows & Dependencies
steps.description: Visualize sequence, handovers, and dependencies.

input: Awareness of relevant human and non-human actors
prompts: This is my user story: [details]. Suggest 3–5 possible use cases.
For this story [details], list potential actors and their roles.
Based on these use cases [list], suggest dependencies or flows between actors.
For these use cases [details], identify hidden risks or ecological trade-offs.
tips: Keep use cases short and action-focused.
Include non-human actors where relevant.
Map multiple paths when possible.
Use early to detect risks and sustainability gaps.

title: Prototyping Playground
overview: Experiment quickly with prototypes to test inclusivity and sustainability early.
purpose: Turn ideas into low-fi prototypes to test flows and uncover accessibility or sustainability issues without heavy investment.

steps.title: Use Basic Elements
steps.description: Start with buttons, inputs, and placeholders.

steps.title: Build Screens
steps.description: Combine elements into flows or layouts.

steps.title: Test with Others
steps.description: Check clarity and accessibility with real users.

steps.title: Adjust Quickly
steps.description: Iterate fast based on feedback.

prompts: I want to prototype [feature]. Suggest 3–5 simple layouts to test flows.
Here’s my prototype: [details]. Suggest accessibility checks I should run.
For this prototype [details], suggest improvements for inclusivity and sustainability.
tips: Start low-fi with simple shapes.
Check contrast, font size, readability.
Keep interactions simple to avoid waste.
Ask if the design works for diverse contexts.
